title: fix async reply not erroring on disjoint replies
Make QuerySubscriber to use accept_replies(ReplyKeyExpr::Any)
body:
Following decision in https://github.com/eclipse-zenoh/roadmap/discussions/55 and its implementation in #334,
the `QueryingSubscriber` needs to be adapted in case its `query_selector` is different than its subscription `key_expr`.

This occurs when the `PublicationCache` is configured with a `prefix` for its queryable: its replies to queries will use the original publications `key_expr`, while the query is on a different `key_expr`.
In such case, the `QueryingSubscriber` needs to use the new `accept_replies(ReplyKeyExpr::Any)` for its queries to the PublicationCache.

title: zenoh-ext: SessionExt operations renaming
body:
To comply with what has been decided in https://github.com/eclipse-zenoh/roadmap/discussions/23 those `SessionExt` operations are renamed as such:
 - `SessionExt::subscribe_with_query` => `SessionExt::declare_querying_subscriber()`
 - `SessionExt::publication_cache()` => `SessionExt::declare_publication_cache()`

title: Mark locality management types and operations unstable
Change default UDP multicast scouting port to 7446
Lowlatency
body:
This PR proposes a new implementation on the transmission pipeline with the goal of reducing the overall latency.

Few numbers comparing the perfs on a test machine equipped with an AMD Ryzen 7 5800X 8-Core Processor.

# Throughput

## Legacy
```
luca@c18:~/zenoh$ ./target/release/examples/z_pub_thr 8 --no-multicast-scouting -e tcp/127.0.0.1:7447 -p 5
```

```
luca@c18:~/zenoh$ ./target/release/examples/z_sub_thr --no-multicast-scouting -l tcp/127.0.0.1:7447 -s 10 -n 1000000
4267262.089694375 msg/s
4274242.895555417 msg/s
4273369.790191731 msg/s
4278778.324924178 msg/s
4285796.3219784545 msg/s
4273432.556539959 msg/s
4284028.97931403 msg/s
4273578.421916209 msg/s
4276858.756388868 msg/s
4280948.733584059 msg/s
```

## New
```sh
luca@c18:~/mallets-zenoh$ ./target/release/examples/z_pub_thr 8 --no-multicast-scouting -e tcp/127.0.0.1:7447 -p 5
```
```sh
luca@c18:~/mallets-zenoh$ ./target/release/examples/z_sub_thr --no-multicast-scouting -l tcp/127.0.0.1:7447 -s 10 -n 1000000
4212208.04206722 msg/s
4243165.87324203 msg/s
4245018.259882369 msg/s
4250149.05060213 msg/s
4240312.124965594 msg/s
4245346.324591207 msg/s
4249325.03296244 msg/s
4239366.46704027 msg/s
4253503.138396249 msg/s
4250568.406197477 msg/s
```

# Latency

## Legacy

```sh
luca@c18:~/zenoh$ ./target/release/examples/z_pong --no-multicast-scouting -l tcp/127.0.0.1:7447
```
```sh
luca@c18:~/zenoh$ ./target/release/examples/z_ping 8 --no-multicast-scouting -e tcp/127.0.0.1:7447 -w 1 -n 10
Warming up for 1s...
8 bytes: seq=0 rtt=38µs lat=19µs
8 bytes: seq=1 rtt=39µs lat=19µs
8 bytes: seq=2 rtt=38µs lat=19µs
8 bytes: seq=3 rtt=39µs lat=19µs
8 bytes: seq=4 rtt=38µs lat=19µs
8 bytes: seq=5 rtt=39µs lat=19µs
8 bytes: seq=6 rtt=37µs lat=18µs
8 bytes: seq=7 rtt=39µs lat=19µs
8 bytes: seq=8 rtt=37µs lat=18µs
8 bytes: seq=9 rtt=39µs lat=19µs
```

## New
```sh
luca@c18:~/mallets-zenoh$ ./target/release/examples/z_pong --no-multicast-scouting -l tcp/127.0.0.1:7447
```
```sh
luca@c18:~/mallets-zenoh$ ./target/release/examples/z_ping 8 --no-multicast-scouting -e tcp/127.0.0.1:7447 -w 1 -n 10
Warming up for 1s...
8 bytes: seq=0 rtt=31µs lat=12µs
8 bytes: seq=1 rtt=25µs lat=12µs
8 bytes: seq=2 rtt=26µs lat=13µs
8 bytes: seq=3 rtt=25µs lat=12µs
8 bytes: seq=4 rtt=26µs lat=13µs
8 bytes: seq=5 rtt=25µs lat=12µs
8 bytes: seq=6 rtt=26µs lat=13µs
8 bytes: seq=7 rtt=26µs lat=13µs
8 bytes: seq=8 rtt=25µs lat=12µs
8 bytes: seq=9 rtt=25µs lat=12µs
```

title: Enable PushMode/PullMode switch for generic SubscriberBuilder
body:
During porting the zenoh-perf to api-changes, I found that the usage of SubscriberBuilder is a little bit counter-intuitive. For example, we can't set the subscriber into `push_mode` since `declare_subscriber` returns a SubscriberBuilder in PushMode by default. And only changes from PushMode to PullMode and converse way are allowed. Maybe let's consider this PR to make the switch be idempotent.

```rust
 let mut subscriber = session
    .declare_subscriber(KEY_EXPR)
    .reliable()
    .push_mode()     // unsupported
    .res()
    .await.unwrap();
```

title: Simplify consolidation to reality, removing strategy
Allow build of zenoh artifacts with specified features
body:
This PR updates the `Cargo.toml` files for `zenohd`, `examples` and `zenoh-ext` crates.
Now all the features are re-exported, thus allowing compilation only of the needed dependencies.

This solves #302, thus now Zenoh can build on FreeBSD.

Now this works.
```
$ cargo build --bin zenohd --example z_pub --example z_sub --no-default-features --features transport_tcp
...
Finished dev [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.16s
```

title: Privatize zenoh net and rationalize prelude
Serial (RS232-like) transport for Zenoh
body:
Hi, this PR contains a transport for Zenoh over Serial ports (RS232-like), it builds atop [Zenoh Serial Framing](https://github.com/ZettaScaleLabs/z-serial) to provide a datagram-based non-reliable abstraction to the Zenoh transport layer.
Wire-encoding leverages on [Consistent Overhead Byte Stuffing (COBS)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consistent_Overhead_Byte_Stuffing).

Sister PR of https://github.com/eclipse-zenoh/zenoh-pico/pull/100

title: WIP: fewer builder types
body:
Remove the unnecessary distinction between `X`, `CallbackX`, and `HandlerX` (where X is Subscriber, Queryable... and their builders). The API is unchanged code-wise, but some typenames have changed (for the better).

This comes with many niceties:
- Build time (all-targets, debug, on a Ryzen 3800x, release seems unaffected): 3m55s -> 2m55s.
- Better naming: who cares that a Subscriber was constructed with a Handler or a Callback? All that matters is what receiver it can deref to so it can be used as a handler when appropriate.
- More approachable API, here's a before/after on the doc for the `subscriber` module's structs, where 10 types have been turned into 6, with less duplication that can lead a reader to start diagonalizing instead of reading:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6801863/183914064-65247dcc-4df2-46f2-a176-7ccc00967f08.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6801863/183914129-6e3a5718-7d32-457c-b665-6a2dc1cf8ca5.png)
- Less code and documentation to maintain: no more having to write everything thrice!

title: CI: Improve Release workflow wrt. Docker builds
body:
Prior to this PR the Release workflow was running for +3h, including +2h to build the Docker images.
This was mainly caused by the build for an arm64 image that was relying on Qemu.
Moreover, the build was [failing sometime](https://github.com/eclipse-zenoh/zenoh/actions/runs/2552804647), probably because of lack of memory in the container

This PR changes the way the Docker images are built:
instead of running the Rust compilation within a Docker container, it's run on the Github runner targeting both `x86_64-unknown-linux-musl` and `aarch64-unknown-linux-musl` platforms, for respectively Alpine x86+64 and arm64 images.
Then, the `.github/workflows/Dockerfile` just copies the binaries (`zenohd` + libs) in Docker images.

Note that I also deactivated the build of examples binaries, as it takes a lot of time and leads to far bigger archives, for unlikely usage.

title: WIP: Keyexpr refactor and some method renaming
GroupManagement: priority configuration
body:
Make configurable the priority of the publications made by the GroupManagement algorithm.
The default priority being set to **DataHigh**.

This should avoid false fault detection that could occur in case of high traffic: the KeepAlive messages will be sent with higher priority than the regular data publications.

title: Fix 275. Fix maximum batched size for streamed-based protocols
Fix query.reply() with a DELETE Sample
body:
When a queryable implementation calls `query.reply(sample)` with `sample.kind == SampleKind::Delete`, the querier receives a sample with `sample.kind == SampleKind::Put`.

The root of the problem is in `Sample::split()` operation that always returns a `DataInfo` with `kind == None`.
This PR fixes copying the `sample.kind` into `DataInfo::kind` (or setting to `None` if `kind == SampleKind::Put` for wire optimisation)

title: Providing the WebSocket transport
body:
This PR provides an implementation for a WebSocket-based transport for Zenoh routers, clients and peers.

- [x] Choice of a locator format `ws/<address>:<port>`  
- [x] Implement the traits for the WebSocket transport: `LinkUnicastTrait`, `LinkManagerUnicastTrait` 
- [x] Add the relevant tests

The feature is disabled by default but the tests can be run with:
```bash
$  cargo test -p zenoh-transport --no-default-features --features transport_ws
```

title: New API to get all (key, timestamp) entries in the database
Example config tidy up. ZenohId config default.
Fix #250. Set the default queue size correctly.
body:
@Mallets this commit resolves the performance regression reported in #250 and inspected in https://github.com/YuanYuYuan/benchmark-zenohd. 

The problem is caused by the buffer size. There are two links created while building zenoh-pico/zn_sub_thr <---> zenohd <---> zenoh/z_pub_thr.
The first link would be created with the option QoS off as well as a conduit of length one (I'm not sure whether it's correct). And then the capacity of the queue is `Priority::Data` by default but NOT after the commit `afa20ff`. 

If we print the TX buffer size, it would look like 

| Commit   | After afa20ff            | Before afa20ff                           |
|----------|--------------------------|------------------------------------------|
| 1st link | [Priority::Control = 1]  | [Priority::Default = Priority::Data = 4] |
| 2nd link | [1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 4, 4, 4] | [1, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4]                 |

Overall, the change of the buffer size in the 2nd link is fine, but the different size in the first link causes the bug.

title: Fix #262. PeerId is renamed to ZenohId
Configuration updates: New rustfmt.toml file and new "fast" Cargo profile
body:
The `rustfmt.toml` configures `rustfmt`. The following options are provided:

```toml
edition = "2018"
use_try_shorthand = true
use_field_init_shorthand = true
```

The fast profile is an addition to builtin debug and release profiles. It's intended to build fast binaries with less compile time, and provide verbose debug information. In order to use the "fast" profile, 

```sh
cargo test --profile fast
```

title: Impl TryFrom<_> for Value. Removed Encoding consts.
Fix #239. subscribe(), get(), put(), delete() builders
Modifying on_sample API of storage management plugin
body: Storage informs back the plugin whether the given sample was used or not.

title: zenoh-ext group: send JoinEvent on KeepAlive for new member
body:
In `zenoh-ext` group management module:
when a member receives a `KeepAlive` message for an unknown member (could happen if it missed the `Join` message for some reason), the group view is correctly updated but no event is triggered to the Group's subscriber. The user has no way to know a new member was discovered, except with regular polling of the group view.

This PR makes sure that a `GroupEvent::Join` event is sent to the Group's subscriber when a new member is detected via its `KeepAlive`.
It also removes up the `NewGroupView` event that was unused and useless since its actually a duplicate of other events which already imply that the group view changed.

title: Replace Gitter badge with Discord badge
A dedicated executor for TX
body: This PR adds a dedicated executor for TX in such a way RX tasks don't eventually block the async runtime for TX.

title: Internal tidy of async/await types and traits towards runtime agnostic code
body:
It's my effort to make zenoh to be less async-std dependent and adopt more runtime-independent types. This patch reduces the usage async-std types in flavor of futures and std. The std is Rust standard, while futures crate is yet to be standard.

* Replace `async_std::sync::{Arc, Weak}` with std's.
* Remove futures-lite crate in flavor of futures crate.
* Use `StreamExt`, `AsyncReadExt` and `AsyncWriteExt` from futures crate. The only exception is `async_std::prelude::FutureExt` because many places uses `FutureExt::race()` and `FutureExt::timeout()`.

title: sift plugin status for 'private'
body: @JEnoch :)

title: Rename Reply.data attribute as Reply.sample
body:
Currently the `Reply` struct as the following definition:
```Rust
pub struct Reply {
    pub data: Sample,
    pub replier_kind: ZInt,
    pub replier_id: PeerId,
}
```
Renaming `data` attribute as `sample` makes more sense since:
 - `Sample` type is not only a "data" but a key/value + context (timestamp, kind, source).
 - in languages where the type is not explicit (Python :eyes:), the attribute name gives a hint

title: zenohd Debian service: add config file (close #191)
body:
This PR adds the following to the **zenohd** debian package:

- a `/etc/zenohd/zenohd.json5` config file which is used by the `zenohd` service.
- a `/var/zenohd` directory which is used as `$ZENOH_HOME` by the `zenohd` service. (i.e. persistent storages will be created under this directory)

- debugging plugin misloads should be easier with the now better error messages

This PR needs sister PRs in each backend, working on that, and I'll run some checks before removing the WIP
